author: donschoe
content:
> If using BLS we talked about a bech32-style encoding of the hash of the public key as an address, which would be nice.
I'm curious if anyone ever worked on that before. If we want to have something like this, we should have it prepared prior to the mainnet launch.

author: carlbeek
content: I spent a far bit of time looking into this. bech-32 cannot represent BLS keys as they have too much entropy. I like the design considerations for bech32, but someone needs to find new polynomials to make this work, and IIRC the extension fields that would work with the bech-32 alphabet were ugly for BLS keys. (They also didn't work nicely for alphabets of size 8)

author: jgm
content: My understanding is that we weren't going to do anything for keys, because they're considered low-level.  The encoding was going to be for the SHA256 hash of the public key (which was being considered as the address).  Not sure if that's still too large for bech-32

author: carlbeek
content: Pubkeys are left as raw bytes within the spec because that is the most efficient encoding anyway. Whether users are presented with the hashes of pubkeys or not I don't think has beed decided. (32 bytes can be encoded with bech32.) I lean against because then transactions would need to provide a witness for the pubkey when the pubkey already exists in the validator registry. Eventually on chain, everything will be stateless anyway, so providing just the full pubkey instead of the hash and the pubkey saves data

author: jgm
content:
> I lean against because then transactions would need to provide a witness for the pubkey when the pubkey already exists in the validator registry
Yeah I thought this was going to be for more of the user/contract accounts (where we're going to be providing witnesses for all transactions anyway, if we are stateless) rather than validator accounts.  But yes, not something that I'd think useful for validator-related operations.
